revision.comment: + {{Military units and formations of the Royal Australian Air Force}}
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{stack begin}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=No. 86 Wing RAAF |image=[[File:No. 86 Wing RAAF crest.gif|125px]] |caption=No. 86 Wing's crest |country=Australia |branch=[[Royal Australian Air Force]] |command_structure=[[Air Mobility Group RAAF|Air Mobility Group]] |garrison=[[RAAF Base Amberley]] |garrison_label=Headquarters |role=Heavy air lift
Light transport
Air-to-air refuelling |dates=1945–64
1987–current |motto=Precision |notable_commanders=[[Angus Houston]] (1994–95) |equipment=[[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III]]
[[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beech King Air 350]]
[[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30]] |equipment_label=Aircraft }} {{command structure |name=No. 86 Wing RAAF |date=2012 |subordinate=[[No. 33 Squadron RAAF|No. 33 Squadron]] (KC-30)
[[No. 36 Squadron RAAF|No. 36 Squadron]] (C-17)
[[No. 38 Squadron RAAF|No. 38 Squadron]] (King Air)
68 Ground Liaison Section (Army) }} {{stack end}} '''No. 86 Wing''' is a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) transport and air-to-air refuelling [[Wing (military aviation unit)|wing]]. Coming under the control of [[Air Mobility Group RAAF|Air Mobility Group]], it is headquartered at [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland. The wing comprises [[No. 33 Squadron RAAF|No. 33 Squadron]], operating [[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30]] [[Aerial refueling|tanker-transports]], [[No. 36 Squadron RAAF|No. 36 Squadron]], operating [[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III]] heavy transports, [[No. 38 Squadron RAAF|No. 38 Squadron]], operating [[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beech King Air 350]] light transports, and the [[Australian Army]]'s 68 Ground Liaison Section. Its aircraft support Australian military and humanitarian operations worldwide. Formed in the last year of [[World War II]] to undertake [[Close air support|ground attack]] missions with [[de Havilland Mosquito]]s and [[Bristol Beaufighter]]s in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]], No. 86 Wing was reorganised in 1946 as a transport formation headquartered at [[RAAF Station Schofields]], New South Wales, flying [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Douglas C-47 Dakotas]]. It relocated to [[RAAF Base Richmond]], New South Wales, in 1949 and began operating [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules]] in 1958. Disbanded in 1964, the wing was re-established at Richmond in 1987, flying [[Boeing 707]] tanker-transports as well as the Hercules. No. 36 Squadron converted to Globemasters in 2006. No. 33 Squadron retired its 707s in 2008, and did not become operational with the KC-30 until 2013. Having previously flown [[de Havilland Canada DHC-4 Caribou]]s, No. 38 Squadron converted to the King Airs in 2009. The Hercules were transferred to [[No. 84 Wing RAAF|No. 84 Wing]] in 2010. No. 86 Wing headquarters relocated from Richmond to Amberley in January 2012. ==History== ===Attack formation (1945–46)=== [[File:No. 1 Squadron RAAF Mosquito (AWM OG3190).jpg|left|thumb|260px||No. 1 Squadron Mosquito, Labuan, August 1945]] Established in March 1945 under the command of [[Group Captain]] J.M. Whyte, No. 86 (Attack) Wing comprised two flying units, [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron]] operating [[de Havilland Mosquito]]s and [[No. 93 Squadron RAAF|No. 93 Squadron]] operating [[Bristol Beaufighter]]s. The wing was initially based on the island of [[Morotai]] in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]], as part of the [[Australian First Tactical Air Force]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/26.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 439–440] Its [[order of battle]] for Operation Oboe Six, the [[Battle of North Borneo|assault on north-west Borneo]] commencing in June, included Nos. 1 and 93 Squadrons, No. 84 Operational Base Unit, No. 30 Air Stores Park, No. 29 Medical Clearing Station, and No. 1 Repair and Servicing Unit—a total of over 1,400 personnel.Waters, ''Oboe'', pp. 57, 110–111 Delays getting the aircraft operational at their forward base on [[Labuan]] meant that the wing only completed three combat missions before the end of the Pacific War, conducting rocket and machine-gun attacks on targets in [[Sarawak]] during August 1945.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/28.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 474–475] No. 1 Squadron took part in one operation and No. 93 Squadron in two; each unit lost one aircraft in action.Parnell; Lynch, ''Australian Air Force Since 1911'', p. 125 No. 86 Wing was originally to have been augmented by a third combat unit, [[No. 94 Squadron RAAF|No. 94 Squadron]], flying Mosquitos. Formed in May 1945, the squadron was still undergoing training when the war ended, and it was disbanded at [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Station Richmond]], New South Wales, in January 1946.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/94sqn.htm |title= No 94 Squadron|publisher=[[RAAF Museum]]|accessdate=30 March 2013}} In December 1945, shortly after the end of the Pacific War, the commanding officer of No. 93 Squadron, Squadron Leader D.K.M. Gulliver, crashed his Beaufighter on takeoff at Labuan, colliding with two [[North American P-51 Mustang|P-51 Mustangs]] of [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|No. 77 Squadron]] parked at the airfield; Gulliver and five people on the ground died in the accident, including the then-Officer Commanding No. 86 Wing, Group Captain L.C.M. Holswich.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=198|title= Beaufighter crash at Labuan|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=30 March 2013}} Between January and March 1946, the Beaufighters escorted Mustangs of [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 Wing]] to Japan for service as part of the [[British Commonwealth Occupation Force]]. In August that year, Nos. 1 and 93 Squadrons disbanded at [[Narromine]], New South Wales.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11127second_world_war.asp|title=93 Squadron RAAF|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=10 April 2013}}Eather, ''Flying Squadrons of the Australian Defence Force'', pp. 20, 100 ===Initial transport formation (1946–64)=== [[File:File-86 Wing (AWM P00448-093).jpg|right|thumb|280px|No. 86 Wing Dakotas during a fly-past in 1952]] Re-formed at [[RAAF Station Schofields]], New South Wales, in July 1946, No. 86 (Transport) Wing was assigned control of [[No. 36 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 36]], [[No. 37 Squadron RAAF|37]], and [[No. 38 Squadron RAAF|38 Squadrons]], flying [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Douglas C-47 Dakotas]].{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=356 |title=86 Wing ran Japan courier service|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 30 March 2013}}Parnell; Lynch, ''Australian Air Force Since 1911'', p. 165 The wing was augmented by No. 386 (Base) Squadron and [[No. 486 Squadron RAAF|No. 486 (Maintenance) Squadron]], formed in August.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 92–93 The Dakotas initially flew supply missions to the Australian-administered [[Territory of Papua and New Guinea]], as well as three-times weekly courier flights to Japan in support of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force. The latter schedule continued until December 1947, when the service was taken over by [[Qantas]] [[Avro Lancastrian]]s. No. 37 Squadron disbanded in February 1948. In August that year, crews from Nos. 36 and 38 Squadrons departed for Europe to [[RAAF Squadron Berlin Air Lift|take part in the Berlin Airlift]], a commitment that lasted almost a year.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 196{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=292 |title=RAAF squadron joined Berlin Airlift|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 30 March 2013}} The Australians were responsible for delivering over 16 million tons of supplies, and almost 8,000 passengers. No. 386 Squadron disbanded in March 1949 and re-formed as Station Headquarters at Schofields.O'Brien, ''Always There'', pp. 54–55 On 22 June 1949, No. 86 Wing, comprising Nos. 36, 38 and 486 Squadrons, relocated from Schofields to the nearby RAAF Station Richmond. The return of crews from Berlin allowed the wing to release No. 38 Squadron and its Dakotas to participate in the [[Malayan Emergency]], under the control of [[No. 90 Wing RAAF|No. 90 (Composite) Wing]], commencing in June 1950. After airlifting more than 17,000 passengers and evacuating over 300 injured troops, the squadron left Malaya in November 1952 and returned to No. 86 Wing at Richmond.Odgers, ''Diggers'', pp. 334–335Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 247–249 A month earlier, the wing's Dakotas had flown supply and observation flights in connection with the [[Operation Hurricane|British atomic test]] on [[Montebello Islands|Montebello]] in Western Australia.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article65504778 |title=Atomic Weapon Tested |newspaper=[[Benalla Ensign]] |location=Victoria |date=27 November 1952 |accessdate=2 April 2013 |page=11 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} No. 36 Squadron disbanded at Richmond on 9 March 1953, re-forming the next day from [[No. 30 Transport Unit RAAF|No. 30 Transport Unit]] at [[Iwakuni, Yamaguchi|Iwakuni]], Japan.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 116{{cite web|author=No. 36 Squadron|title =Operations Record Book | url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=1358988&I=1&SE=1 |page=41|publisher= [[National Archives of Australia]]|date=1950–1966| accessdate=2 April 2013}} Here it was part of [[No. 91 Wing RAAF|No. 91 (Composite) Wing]], which controlled the RAAF's units during the [[Korean War]] and its immediate aftermath.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 232 The squadron returned to Australia and the aegis of No. 86 Wing two years later, when No. 91 Wing disbanded.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 94{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=404 |title=No 91 (Composite) Wing formed in Japan|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=2 April 2013}} [[File:RAAF C-130A Hercules (AWM 128872).jpeg|260px|thumb|left|RAAF C-130A Hercules of No. 36 Squadron]] In 1954, No. 86 Wing relocated to [[Fairbairn, Canberra|Canberra]] to help satisfy the Federal government's [[Very Important Person|VIP]] transport needs. It returned to Richmond four years later, leaving behind its VIP contingent, No. 34 Flight, which in July 1959 was re-formed as [[No. 34 Squadron RAAF|No. 34 Squadron]] and left the control of No. 86 Wing to become an independent unit directly administered by [[RAAF Air Command|Home Command]] and tasked by RAAF Canberra.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 416, 426RAAF Historical Section, ''Maritime and Transport Units'', p. 46 Having earlier augmented its complement of Dakotas with [[Convair CV-240 family|Convair 440 Metropolitan]]s, in December 1958 the wing began operating [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules]] medium transports, when No. 36 Squadron took delivery of the first of twelve C-130As. They remained in service for twenty years, clocking up 147,000 accident-free flying hours.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 97–98{{cite web |url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series2/A97.htm |title= Lockheed Hercules |publisher=RAAF Museum |accessdate=2 April 2013}} The official history of the post-war Air Force described the Hercules as "probably the biggest step-up in aircraft capabilities" the RAAF ever received, considering it roughly four times as effective as the Dakota, taking into account the improvements in payload, range, and speed.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 417 When [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 (Fighter) Wing]] and its two [[CAC Sabre]] squadrons deployed to [[RMAF Base Butterworth|RAAF Base Butterworth]] between October 1958 and February 1959, seven Dakotas were required to ferry the staff and equipment of [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] from Australia to [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]], compared to two Hercules for [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|No. 77 Squadron]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 259–260 In 1962, Air Movements and Training Flight (AMTF), previously under No. 38 Squadron and responsible for developing and imparting new techniques in aerial transport, came directly under the control of No. 86 Wing headquarters.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 99 That December, the Hercules carried troops into a combat zone for the first time, when one of No. 36 Squadron's C-130s joined a Commonwealth airlift from Singapore to Borneo at the beginning of the [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|''Konfrontasi'']] between Indonesia and Malaysia; similar missions were undertaken for another five years.{{cite web|title=RAAF C-130 at start of Confrontation|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=168|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=6 April 2013}} No. 38 Squadron received the RAAF's first [[de Havilland Canada DHC-4 Caribou]] tactical transports in April 1964, replacing its Dakotas. The first six Caribous were despatched that August to South East Asia for service in the [[Vietnam War]] as RAAF Transport Flight Vietnam (RTFV). The same month, No. 86 Wing was disbanded.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 102, 114Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 259–260 Because the Caribous were primarily for support of the [[Australian Army]], an overarching wing headquarters for the Caribous and Hercules was now considered inappropriate. No. 486 Squadron was also disbanded and its equipment and staff divided between Nos. 36 and 38 Squadrons, which along with AMTF became independently operating units under the command of Headquarters RAAF Base Richmond.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 424–425 Following the re-establishment at Richmond of No. 37 Squadron in February 1966, flying C-130E Hercules, No. 486 Squadron was re-formed to provide maintenance for both Hercules squadrons. As No. 36 Squadron's tasking was mainly tactical and No. 37 Squadron's strategic (owing to the longer range of its C-130Es), forming the Hercules units into a new wing was not deemed necessary. Still based at Richmond, the Hercules provided long-range transport and medical evacuation services to and from South East Asia during the Vietnam War.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 100 No. 36 Squadron's C-130As were replaced by C-130H models in 1978. RTFV was re-formed as [[No. 35 Squadron RAAF|No. 35 Squadron]] in June 1966, and continued to serve in Vietnam until Australian forces were withdrawn in 1972; it was then based in Richmond until 1976, when it relocated to [[RAAF Base Townsville]], Queensland.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 262–263 No. 38 Squadron meanwhile continued to operate Caribous out of Richmond until 1992, when it transferred to [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland.{{cite web |url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/38sqn.htm |title= No 38 Squadron |publisher=RAAF Museum |accessdate=2 April 2013}} In the Vietnam and post-Vietnam eras, along with their military transport duties, the Hercules and Caribou undertook disaster relief operations throughout Australia and the Pacific.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 103–104 ===Current transport formation (1987–)=== [[File:Royal Australian Air Force DHC-4 Caribou - A4-299 - 01.jpg|260px|thumb|right|RAAF DHC-4 Caribou, October 2009]] No. 86 Wing re-formed at Richmond on 2 February 1987, under the newly established [[Air Lift Group RAAF|Air Lift Group]] (ALG), which replaced Headquarters RAAF Base Richmond. Commanded by Group Captain G.I. Lumsden, the wing's flying units consisted of [[No. 33 Squadron RAAF|No. 33 Squadron]], operating [[Boeing 707]] [[Aerial refueling|tanker-transports]], and Nos. 36 and 37 Squadrons, operating C-130H and C-130E Hercules, respectively; No. 486 Maintenance Squadron and [[Air Movements Training and Development Unit RAAF|Air Movements Training and Development Unit]] (AMTDU), which had evolved from AMTF in 1965, were also under its control.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 107–108, 115 No. 486 Squadron was responsible for day-to-day maintenance of the 707s as well as the Hercules.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maintenance Units'', pp. 70–71 No. 34 Squadron, the VIP transport unit based at [[Fairbairn, Canberra|RAAF Base Fairbairn]] in Canberra, and [[No. 32 Squadron RAAF|No. 32 Squadron]], flying [[Hawker Siddeley HS 748]] air navigation trainers at [[RAAF Base East Sale]] in Victoria, became part of No. 86 Wing in June 1988 and July 1989, respectively. In 1992, the Hercules of Nos. 36 and 37 Squadrons clocked up a grand total of 500,000 accident-free flying hours; Lockheed presented No. 86 Wing with a trophy to commemorate the milestone.{{cite magazine|magazine= RAAF News |volume=34 |issue=6|title=Symbol of success|date= July 1992|page=18}} During 1994–95, the wing was commanded by Group Captain (later Air Chief Marshal) [[Angus Houston]], who in 2005 was appointed [[Chief of the Defence Force (Australia)|Chief of the Defence Force]], only the third RAAF officer to be raised to the top position in the Australian armed services.{{cite web |url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Chief-Marshals/132/Air-Chief-Marshals.aspx |title=Air Chief Marshals |accessdate=2 April 2013 |work=Air Marshals of the RAAF |publisher=Air Power Development Centre}}{{cite web| last=Clark|first=Dr Chris| title=Air Force Defence chiefs of the past| date= 19 May 2005 | url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4708/history/story02.htm |work=[[Air Force (newspaper)|Air Force]], Volume 47, No. 8 | accessdate=2 April 2013}} By mid-1996, No. 32 Squadron had been transferred to [[No. 84 Wing RAAF|No. 84 Wing]], which was also controlled by ALG.{{cite magazine|title=32 Squadron multi-role|magazine=Air Force Today |volume=1 |issue=1|date=May 1996|pages=30–31}} In 1998, No. 86 Wing received the [[Gloucester Cup|Duke of Gloucester Cup]] as the most proficient wing in [[RAAF Air Command]].{{cite magazine|title=Recognition for 501 Wing|magazine=Air Force News |volume=40 |issue=3|date= April 1998|page=6}} No. 486 Squadron was disbanded in October that year, after transferring its functions to Nos. 36 and 37 Squadrons.{{cite magazine|title=Bulletin board|magazine=Air Force News |volume=40 |issue=8|date=September 1998| page=12}} By then, Nos. 35 and 38 Squadrons, flying Caribous out of RAAF Bases Townsville and Amberley, respectively, had joined the Hercules squadrons and AMTDU under the aegis of No. 86 Wing, while Nos. 33 and 34 Squadrons had been transferred to No. 84 Wing, now also headquartered at Richmond.{{cite book|title=Defence Annual Report 1997–98|chapter=Australian Defence Force Units and Establishments|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/budget/97-98/dar/full.pdf|publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]]|accessdate=16 May 2013|page=53}} Later, AMTDU became part of [[No. 85 Wing RAAF|No. 85 Wing]] at Richmond.{{cite book|title=Defence Annual Report 2001–02|chapter=ADF Units and Establishments|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/budget/01-02/dar/appendix.pdf|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=2 April 2013|page=330}} No. 37 Squadron's C-130Es were replaced by C-130J models in 1999. No. 35 Squadron transferred its Caribous to No. 38 Squadron in 2000, and was "formally deactivated" in March 2002.{{cite web |url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/35sqn.htm |title= No 35 Squadron |publisher=RAAF Museum |accessdate=2 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.raaf.gov.au/organisation/info_on/groups/air_lift_group.htm|title=Air lift Group (ALG)|publisher= [[Royal Australian Air Force]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050722041553/http://www.raaf.gov.au/organisation/info_on/groups/air_lift_group.htm|archivedate= 22 July 2005|accessdate=2 April 2013}} RAAF C-130 operations were concentrated in No. 37 Squadron in November 2006, when No. 36 Squadron transferred its C-130Hs prior to [[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III in Australian service|re-equipping with]] the [[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III]] heavy transports and relocating to Amberley.{{cite web|title=Royal Australian Air Force squadrons celebrate new role |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/DepartmentalTpl.cfm?CurrentId=6145 |publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=17 November 2006}} No. 38 Squadron's Caribous were retired at the end of 2009, and replaced by [[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beech King Air 350]] light transports.{{cite web|title=Caribou flies into history|url=http://dev-wp.australianaviation.com.au/caribou-flies-into-history/|work=[[Australian Aviation (magazine)|Australian Aviation]]|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=27 November 2009}} No. 37 Squadron was transferred to No. 84 Wing in October 2010.{{cite web|title=Restructure of Air Lift Group units |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/download/2010/Oct/20101005c/index.htm|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=5 October 2010}} [[File:RAAF C-17 Afghanistan.jpg|left|thumb|300px|RAAF C-17 Globemaster taxiing at Tarin Kowt airfield in Afghanistan, December 2010]] The aircraft operated by No. 86 Wing became well known to the general public through their involvement in disaster relief and emergency transport in Australia and the region, along with their participation in overseas peacekeeping efforts.{{cite news|last=Webb|first=Helena|title=Flying to safety: how the RAAF responds to nations in crisis|date=10 October 2005 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|url= http://www.abc.net.au/wa/stories/s1478966.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051025105255/http://www.abc.net.au/wa/stories/s1478966.htm|archivedate=25 October 2005|accessdate=8 April 2013}}McPhedran, ''Air Force'', pp. 32–35 Hercules and 707s were employed by the Federal government to provide air transport during the [[1989 Australian pilots' dispute|pilots' dispute]] that curtailed operations by the two domestic airlines in 1989, evacuated Australian nationals from the Middle East during the first [[Gulf War]] in 1990–91,Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 110–111 and transported Australian troops to and from Somalia as part of [[Operation Solace]] in 1993.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=131 |title=Advance party headed for Somalia|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=2 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=450|title=Airlift returned Army battalion from Somalia|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=2 April 2013}} Since the end of the Vietnam War, much of the RAAF's transport tasking had been relatively routine in nature, or involved humanitarian relief; the Somalia operation marked the beginning of a shift for No. 86 Wing towards a more combat-ready or "operational" focus. Six Hercules evacuated over 450 civilians from Cambodia following the [[1997 clashes in Cambodia|coup in July 1997]].{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=211|title= Cambodian coup prompted airlift|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=2 April 2013}} Two detachments from the wing, one of Hercules and one of Caribous, supported [[International Force for East Timor|INTERFET]] operations in [[East Timor]] between September 1999 and February 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/east_timor/raaf/|title=RAAF units in East Timor|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]] |accessdate=30 March 2013}} Wing operations staff accompanied Hercules of Nos. 36 and 37 Squadrons on relief efforts following the [[2002 Bali Bombings|Bali Bombings]] in October 2002.{{cite web| last=Eaton|first= Mark| title='Full-on' efforts earn plaudits| date= 24 October 2002 | url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4420/topstories/story04.htm |work=Air Force News, Volume 44, No. 20 | accessdate=2 April 2013}} In February 2003, a rotating detachment of three Hercules deployed to the [[Persian Gulf]] to support the [[Operation Slipper|Australian contribution to the wars in Afghanistan]] and [[Australian contribution to the 2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq]]; over the next seven years they amassed 20,000 operational flying hours.McPhedran, ''Air Force'', p. 11{{cite web|title=Aussie Hercs clock 20,000 operational hours |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/download/media/pressrel/Z7AW6/upload_binary/z7aw60.pdf;fileType=application%2Fpdf#search=%22media/pressrel/Z7AW6%22 |publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=2 April 2013|date= 25 March 2010}} From July 2003 to July 2004, Caribous undertook reconnaissance and transport missions during the [[Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands|Solomon Islands intervention]].{{cite journal|title=The DHC-4 Caribou's 45 years service |url = http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/admin/productfiles/publication/materials/408/pathfinder_125_dec09%20small.pdf|work=Pathfinder, Issue 125|date =December 2009|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 2 April 2013}}McPhedran, ''Air Force'', p. 71 No. 36 Squadron Hercules took part in [[Operation Sumatra Assist]] in the wake of the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|2004 Boxing Day tsunami]].{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=539|title=Relief effort after Boxing Day tsunami|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 2 April 2013}} The RAAF's contribution to [[Operation Papua New Guinea Assist]], following [[Cyclone Guba]] in November 2007, included a Globemaster, two Hercules, and three Caribous.{{cite web|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|title=PNG Assist takes off |url=http://digital.realviewtechnologies.com/?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&iid=5940 |work=Air Force News, Vol. 49, No. 22|page=3|accessdate=2 April 2013|date= 29 November 2007}}{{cite web|last=Gardiner|first=Kris|author2=Stackpool, Andrew |title=PNG mercy mission |url=http://digital.realviewtechnologies.com/?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&iid=6095 |work=Air Force News, Vol. 49, No. 23|page=5|accessdate=2 April 2013|date= 13 December 2007}} In September 2008, a Globemaster undertook the type's first aeromedical evacuation in RAAF service, transporting five injured Australian troops to Amberley from [[Tarinkot|Tarin Kowt]] in Afghanistan.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=107|title=C-17 on first medical evacuation mission|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 2 April 2013}} Globemasters, Hercules and King Airs were all employed for [[2010–2011 Queensland floods|flood relief in Queensland]] and [[Early 2011 Victorian floods|Victoria early in 2011]].{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/Operations/Humanitarian-support/?RAAF-hruuHkflEaNxq4BtnrEKSQz5XM3LaPec|title=Humanitarian support|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=6 May 2013}}{{cite web|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|title=Flood assist |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/5301/5301.pdf |work=Air Force, Vol. 53, No. 1|pages=4–5|accessdate=16 May 2013|date= 3 February 2011}} In February that year, Globemasters and Hercules transported medical staff and equipment to New Zealand to aid victims of the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|Christchurch earthquake]]. The following month, a Globemaster flew 23 sorties in Japan supporting relief efforts after the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]], while two other Globemasters delivered a water cannon to help contain damage at the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant]].McPhedran, ''Air Force'', pp. 237–238 On 1 January 2012, No. 86 Wing headquarters relocated from Richmond to Amberley.{{cite web|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|work=Air Force News, Vol. 54, No. 1|title=86WG now calls Amberley home|date =2 February 2012|url=http://digital.realviewtechnologies.com/?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&iid=58813|page=10|accessdate=2 April 2013}} ALG was renamed Air Mobility Group on 1 April 2014.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=6&iid=91526|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|title=Symbolic change is perfect timing|magazine=Air Force |volume=56 |issue=8|date=8 May 2014|page=7|accessdate=5 May 2014}} No. 86 Wing's current complement is: No. 33 Squadron, which became operational with the [[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30]] tanker-transport after receiving the fourth of its aircraft in March 2013; No. 36 Squadron, which took delivery of its eight and last Globemaster in November 2015; No. 38 Squadron, operating King Airs; and the Australian Army's 68 Ground Liaison Section.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Mobility-Group/No.-86-Wing/?RAAF-L/vGzk7TMG7p5QeGWqFzal55alCa8iJ6 |title= No. 86 Wing|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate= 30 November 2015}}{{cite web| last=Hamilton|first=Eamon| title=Tanker ready for ops| date= 14 March 2013 | url=http://digital.realviewtechnologies.com/?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&iid=74845 |work=Air Force News, Volume 55, No. 4 | page=3| accessdate=2 April 2013}}{{cite magazine| url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=131970&startpage=2#folio=2|title=Fleet complete|magazine=Air Force |volume=57 |issue=22|date=19 November 2015|page=3|accessdate=16 November 2015}} All units are based at Amberley, with the exception of No. 38 Squadron, located at Townsville. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite book|last=Eather|first=Steve|title=Flying Squadrons of the Australian Defence Force|publisher=Aerospace Publications|location=Weston Creek, Australian Capital Territory|year=1995|isbn=1-875671-15-3}} *{{cite book|last=McPhedran| first=Ian|author-link=Ian
